attributes.comment:
I oppose the plan to increase filing fees, especially those associated with international
adoptions. International adoptions already cost more than $15,000 and these potential increases
will continue to place unfair and unnecessary burdens on loving families eager to adopt
internationally. The justification for increasing fees to improve efficiency and account for
homeland security issues is flawed, as is the reason that fees have not been increased in a
while. A brief review of the fee history shows that fees for the I-600 alone have increased by 250
percent since 1994, and the proposed increase will push that over 300 percent. The N-600
increases have been as bad, and the proposal will place the increase at more than 350 percent
since 1994. Increasing fees as a claim to improve efficiency does not sit well with either me or
my wife, given that CIS lost paperwork associated with our I-600 application this past year,
prolonging what is supposed to be a three-month process into twice that. Whatever problems
exist in processing paperwork cannot be solved by simply passing the cost along to the
applicant. And requiring adopting families to undergo even more background checks, etc., in the
name of homeland security makes no sense. I recognize that the nation must protect its citizens
and borders from the threat of terrorism, but someone please explain to me what threat to
national security is posed by adopting families and the orphaned children, usually less than a
year old?

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Lance W. Speere
